commentBody: Much easier than Friday (for me). And that's all I'm going to say about that.

Just a really nice flow to this puzzle. Interestingly, I'd skip a clue, hopeless, only to quickly double back on a cross as the answer clicked. I panicked on the riyal/repair cross - my brain kept trying to fill in an 'o' instead of an 'i' there and I couldn't keep my eyes off the clock. But then it fell into place, like the rest of the puzzle did; an interesting experience. I just might have caught the author's wavelength.

Feisty. Quick. 

Conservatively, I counted 30-plus clues that were plain trivia. 

It wasn‚Äôt a bad puzzle, but I was not Saturday-level entertained. 

Kudos for including Sartre on a longish entry. Puzzles that require having read a book or two make for better puzzles. 

Happy Friday night to everyone; Happy Saturday morning to fellow insomniacs.

YESINDEEDY, I enjoyed this puzzle.  It was a ROLLICKING good time, despite my trying frolicking first.  I cruised through the top two thirds in good order, but bogged down a bit in the bottom third, thanks to the aforementioned frolicking fiasco and having ante for pot filler before getting STEW.  I still finished relatively quickly for a Saturday, but thought the puzzle was loaded with fresh clues and answers, which compensated for the relative ease of completion.

TIL the term NAPTRAPPED.  I‚Äôm familiar with the concept, although in my family it is usually a cat or dog that does the napping and trapping.

first ever saturday! ü•≥

i had a great time with this one. am i entitled to any PRIZEMONEY? lol

Anyone care to join our club - Sam‚Äôs* and mine - it‚Äôs the Nap-Trapped by Catnapping Lap Cats Club. 

*Corbin. But, Sam Lyons, I‚Äôm sure you are a member too.
FIRSTOFALL, I was caught FLATFOOTED by NAPTRAPPED and PTOWN, but eventually I OBVI earned my PRIZEMONEY (grand total: 0 RIYALS) by finishing faster than usual.
Top shelf puzzle. Bravo!
Goon trial
Pretty fun challenge! NW was the last to fall for me

I had a ROLLICKING good time. Admittedly a hefty serving of both trivia and tricky/misleading clues; and admittedly I knew a fair amount of the former, and I believe you can never have too much of the latter (a minority opinion, perhaps). Maybe it‚Äôs just the way my mind thinks; I‚Äôm embarrassed how quickly I came up with WONDERBRA. Wonderful seed entry in NAPTRAPPED (new to me, but I‚Äôll be sure to use it from now on). I could list more favorite clues but too many to count. I will call out ProvinceTOWN; a lovely little place that is worth a trip to if you are up that way. I know it because they have a Tennessee Williams festival every year and my son frequently directs shows there; his first coincidentally was Mae West‚Äôs SEX. Welcome back after your crossword hiatus Kyle!
This was an easy Saturday ansd I am not complaining.
So, second themeless Wednesday in a row. Dont get me wrong. It was fun to solve.  The combo that had me most flumoxed was Ducks on ice/ANAHEIM. OBVI.

My comment was emu‚Äôd and may be people‚Äôd too once it gets a second ‚Äúlook.‚Äù  I‚Äôll give a SFW abridged version:

I spotted three genres within the puzzle:  1) Spicy Romance, in which our female ACTION HERO has ROLLICKING HOT OIL the subject of ‚Äúthe talk‚Äù; 2) ANTI-NOVEL, in which our former ACTION HERO lives IN TERROR and feels as FLAT-FOOTED as an AHI at a FISH FRY; and 3) Romance, which features an OPAL exchange at a CHAPEL accompanied by Chick COREA‚Äôs ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Everything,‚Äù followed by our HERO‚Äôs happy ending straight out of SHONDALAND.

If I was someone who wrote gratitude lists, I‚Äôd put NYT crosswords near the top of my list.
Well at least it was harder than yesterday...

I did this tucked up in bed.  Not really a Saturday, more of a warm and comfy sweater of a puzzle that I moved through enjoying the wit and rhythm of the solve. The constructor‚Äôs comments were the perfect ending for my day.

Please tell me I'm not the only one who thought 31D was a tennis reference. I pretty confidently had TENNISKIT in there. It made sense. The E and first I were 100% certain from the crossings. Took me a while to work around that

When the mathematician made dessert, the proofs were in the pudding.

(It came with a slice of pi.)
A great puzzle! Thanks, Kyle! Y‚Äôall have a stupendous Saturday!
A Saturday that I sat IN TERROR of, but found myself ROLLICKING.  thanks!!

Thanks to everyone who cheered me on yesterday - I got the gold star today and finally got my first 6 day streak! Woohoo! ü•≥ 

Loved 1A and 30D. Such a fun puzzle!
"WONDERBRA," really? Really??

43:45, 16:57 faster than average. 25:00 for 3/4th of the puzzle and nearly the same for the top-right.

Being 1A sometimes got me out of chores (guilty) and made for some cute pictures. Absolutely miss it.

Another quick one, but I enjoyed the fill. FIRST OF ALL, my in-laws live on Cape Cod, so Province TOWN was a gimme. I‚Äôm also a big fan of Keanu Reeves and Bruce Willis, so ACTION HERO just plopped itself in there. As a SoCal native, the ANAHEIM Ducks another gimme. Even though I‚Äôm a Halloween baby, I‚Äôm not a fan of scary movies and I would definitely react IN TERROR if I had to sit through one üò¨ I could go on and on about how the puzzle intersects with my life, but I will just say that I was on the same wavelength as Kyle. Thank you for a breezy Saturday grid.

After seeing the positive comments here I guess I'm very much in the minority but this is the first time I've given up on a puzzle without getting even half of the answers, which is worse by degrees of magnitude than anything I've ever done before.  I refuse to look up answers and probably complete Saturday puzzles 80% of the time but this was a total zero for me. Is anyone else out there in my situation?

I was so sure the Sartre clue was about his refusal to accept the CUP and the fill was ANTINObEL.  OBVI I'm a little behind the times slangwise.

Nice puzzle, Kyle.  I enjoyed it.

Overall a fun one, albeit still on the easy side for a Saturday - though not as ridiculously easy as yesterday, at least! One little clue that stumped me on the initial read-through, though, was 49, as I had never heard of the second monster.

It was a late finish for yesterday's puzzle, so no comment from me; not quite as late (or early) this morning, so I've got a bit of time to discourse before bedtime.

Liked both puzzles, and ended up with Saturday's being a minute or so faster than Friday's; thought that they were both on the easier side for weekend puzzles. Lots of fun answers and some nice misdirection made them interesting, and entertaining. Today's solve was like a U, with a run down the left side and then a slant up to the NE, with a final run to the SE to finish things off.

Like a few others, NAP TRAPPED was a new one as I haven't had that experience for over three decades. Remembered the Disney hockey movie and their subsequent ownership of the  ANAHEIM team, first named the Mighty Ducks, after the movie. 

A few places needed help from the crosses, but it solved surprisingly quickly. Thanks, Kyle!

Had to do a few lookups when I became totally stuck, but that‚Äôs ok. This is how we learn. (To add to the discussion from yesterday, I only look up factual terms, not wordplay. And only when I‚Äôve exhausted all guesses. These are my personal rules, and they‚Äôre designed only to keep me from being lazy.)

I was amused by NAPTRAPPED, mostly because I‚Äôve never heard the term before. But I can relate. Not from children, but from spouses. And dogs. And cats. Basically, anyone who wants to plant themself upon you. I‚Äôve learned to take it as a compliment. I‚Äôm just that cozy! üòÅ

I started out with lAPTRAncES 
which I was rather proud of, though it certainly made my solve rather difficult.  

I had to resort to Wikipedia for some trivia to get my PRIZE.   I consoled myself by remembering many  cozy, serene experiences of baby-, dog-, and cat- NAPTRAPPing!
I worked on this puzzle using NYTimes App, but it wouldn‚Äôt fill in all the letters I typed, leaving blanks.  Hard to solve invisible puzzle.  Anyone know why this happened?

Well, I figured it to be LAP TRAPPED and that LASTY is the new way of saying incredibly bad. People, or things, that often (if not always) comesin last (in a race, or a taste test) must be incredibly bad to attain such dishonor. Those people, or things, are so...LASTY! And lasty is worse than nasty any day of the week.

I'm serious!

Yup, the GOON TRIAL. Goons -- in the NHL -- are "enforcers" -- they spend a lot of time in the penalty box for deliberately provoking targets on the opposing team, often in fights, often in trouble for flagrant fouls. In the good ol' days "there was a fight and a hockey game broke out," and the Penguins didn't have a goon on the squad per se, but we did have Ulf Samuelson and he was not only an excellent defender but could DO DIRTY on you, often while the refs weren't looking.  We loved him, but the goons on opposing teams, like Tie Domi, we thought deserved to be put on GOON TRIAL and maybe spend some time in the Big Penalty Box instead!

Anyone here play the Tiles game Utrecht? I have a question about it but don't see anyway to ask. I have asked via the Feedback tab, but that is not set up to respond. It's just a one way survey.  Can someone tell me how to contact the Tiles editors(?) to get a response?

I was almost able to fill the grid without lookups, but I broke down in the SE corner and googled Freud's rat man. Of course I'm familiar with OCD, but must it be clued so arcanely, even on a Saturday?

That area of the puzzle was super hard for me in general. I have no idea why it's bad to be caught FLAT FOOTED - I wanted red handed, but it wouldn't fit. Is it some expression I don't know? Apparently. I thought I knew what it meant but now I'm doubting myself.

"Xxx tootin'" solving to YES INDEEDY was beyond cruel for a non-American solver. It's what I get for coming here as a Pole...

What on Earth is a PUPU platter? 

I finally inferred "PALS around", but it was new to me, too.

And don't get me started on PUDGY baby fingers... It is one of the di5turbing qualities of babies that puts me off them. But at least I knew the word.

Another problem spot was around DO DIRTY. I did not know that phrase, nor was I familiar with LEE as clued. I also had no idea REPENT could be used with "of". Finally, I've had my fair share of hair therapy (with a mane of hair to show for it), but hot oil never came into it.

I have fond memories of the WONDERBRA brand. As a teenager I visited London, and I was fascinated by this amazing metropolis, so different and so much more exciting than the dreary Warsaw of the early 90s. I loved almost everything about it, but one of my favorite sights were giant billboards of the supermodel Eva Herzigova advertising WONDERBRA ü§£

Fairly straightforward here. The last fill was the very top left. Had LAPTRAPPED. Finally got the star (just shy of 1800 streak) at 16:24, 6:47 better than my average.

Thanks, Kyle. Enjoyed it!

That was an upside-down week, for my solve times.  Fastest to slowest:
‚ÄîFriday
‚ÄîSaturday
‚ÄîMonday
‚ÄîTuesday (Worcestershire)
‚ÄîThursday (wheels)
‚ÄîWednesday (duck rabbit)
Wed was 2.2 x Fri
Enjoyed them all

Took me forever, in fact as I was writing this comment, to parse 18A, not had by = ONTO. "I'm ON TO you." The rest of the grid was nice and challenging, but I was totally stuck at NONO and ONTO. Plus not being super hip on Sartre terms.

Minor nit: a JIB is set on the forestay, which is in front of the foremast (or just mast if there's only one). The jib is not really set "on the front of a foremast", but in front of. Yes, the top point of the sail is attached to the mast, but that's all. The luff, or forward edge of the jib, is attached to the forestay. That said, what other 3-letter sail is there?

For me that was hard. 

SHONDALAND, ERNO, PTOWN, DODIRTY all unknowns. 

It was heavy on USAisms (eg PUPU, COBB) which makes it a bit of a slog for those not living your culture. Fish and Lent is universal but FISHFRY was news to me. 

Anyway, it turned out ok. 

Teat for organic energy source was the last to be switched out. 

Thanks

TIL that the anagrammatic roc of 49A, rather straightforwardly - univocally, even - inferred, is a gigantic mythic bird in these parts which can best elephants with ease. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roc_(mythology)

'"That way" is not an accurate clue for YON. The proper solution to that would be the adverb YONDER: "He's over that way"; "He's over yonder." YON is a demonstrative adjective, like THIS or THAT, and precedes a noun: "he's over by yon tree." (Originally THIS meant near the speaker, THAT meant near the interlocutor, and YON meant away from both. Over time the meaning of YON got folded into THAT.)
Re: the Mini, if a marathon were only 20k, I‚Äôd be a marathon man :)

Really enjoyed that! Tough and I had nothing for a while. Lots of American stuff that I didn‚Äôt know but so satisfying to finally slog it to completion. 
I had ‚Äòin horror‚Äô for a while which held me up for a bit‚Ä¶ 
Good puzzle.
Good puzzle. In retrospect, it went by pretty quickly.

The NW slowed me down a bit.  I was only sure of P-TOWN and PEAT.

Just when I memorized Rubik's first name, I see I have another ERNO to remember.

Give me music, food, and animals and I'm unstoppable, but organized sports, movies and TV shows are never at the tip of my pencil.  Good little challenge in an otherwise quick solve.

NAP-TRAPPED.  Hah!  OMG!  One of our sons took forever to go to sleep at night, as a baby.  It would never happen without intervention ‚Äì lullabies, stories, holding while gently swaying.  During the latter, he would often, finally, drop into sleep.  But that wasn‚Äôt enough.  You had to hold him longer until he dropped deeper; you were nap-trapped.  

Finally, finally he would ever-so-gently be laid down, and you would tiptoe out, and then came the 30 seconds where you waited IN TERROR, because half the time he‚Äôd wail anew, and you‚Äôd have to do it all over again.

This is a memory now infused with smiles and love, and thank you for triggering it, Kyle.  

And thank you for more:
‚Ä¢	That gorgeous SE stack of FLAT-FOOTED, ROLLICKING, and YES INDEEDY.  Mwah!
‚Ä¢	Puzzle-sparking Scrabbliness, a Q short of a pangram.
‚Ä¢	Five double-O‚Äôs, including the lovely dook GOONTRIAL.
‚Ä¢	A terrific new clue for ACHOO ‚Äì [Exclamation made while covering the face].
‚Ä¢	PuzzPairs¬© of PUPU/NONO and WONDERBRA/CUP.

I left this grid feeling good all over ‚Äì a gift.  Thank you for a splendid outing, Kyle!

Good puzzle. Took me forever to get the SE corner, but I eventually did it. My only nit is the clue for phlox. Phlox come in many colors, so "purple" was a misdirect, IMO. It wasn't too serious, though, since it's the only flower I know of that ends in x.
Lovely grab bag of trivia

Started out right away with a gimme - PTOWN. When I was in college I went there a few times with a friend. We just thought it would be a cool place to go. And it was. Except for the fact that she was tall, slim,natural blonde, and drop-dead gorgeous, and I was quite the opposite. Walking down the street with her did nothing for my ego. She was such a looker that even the women couldn't take their eyes off her. It was only after our second excursion there that I learned why women kept looking at her. There was no LGBTQ terminology in those days, but my mom later told me that it was that way even that way when she was young. More that 50 years later, my friend is still beautiful. And I'm still short.

To add insult to that long-ago injury, I'm having trouble with my eyes, so I put PTOWN in the wrong place. Not a big deal for you online solvers, but a disaster for my pen on paper solve. Caught it, though, and went on to finish the puzzle rather quickly.

Sam (Corbin), I like to call it "laptrapped" when a cat has me pinned down ‚Ä¶. üò∫

Alas, many years since that has happened, due to guilt over trapping a cat in an apartment that stays empty of humans for fourteen or more hours at a time. 

Swell puzzle. Tough, but still finished close to my usual time.
Has anyone else noticed that today's ANTINOVEL and yesterday's ANTIRACIST are in nearly the same position in the puzzle?

This puzzle brings my streak to 365. A full year of consecutive successful solves. This one was a bit of a toughie for me. Nearly 9 minutes over my average. Not sure if the anticipated milestone clouded the mind a bit, or if this was the challenge a Saturday grid should be, either way I think I‚Äôll celebrate with a hearty breakfast.

Typical tough Saturday for me, with a few complete unknowns and others that were never going to dawn on me just from the clues. A little bit of cheating but otherwise managed to slog through it. No complaints. Interesting puzzle find today - a Thursday from June 21, 2001 by Peter Abide. The 'reveal' in that one: Electrical device with a hint to answering 17-, 27- and 48-Across : ONOFFSWITCH And... those clues and answers: "Management group for a pro team :" FROFFTONICE ""A Star Is Born" co-star :" KRISTONERSOFF "Gridiron ploy :" OFFSIDEKICKON Always nice to see something different. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/21/2001&g=63&d=A ...

An excellent Saturday offering, and a very well constructed grid. All the long entries were solid, and even the short fill was good.

Got this solved without assistance, but took almost thirty minutes. Wouldn't mind a bit more challenge on a Saturday, but this was a very fine puzzle.

GOON TRIAL seems to be crying out for a cute and clever clue.

As a relative newbie, I enjoyed today's puzzel, having to use autocorrect only for the last few words, as 10D and 25A were not phrases I've heard before.

I do appreciate the ever-present, obligatory sports team name clue! Cheers, folks.

Today's walk down memory lane:  the PUPU platter!

The very mention of the word takes me back to visits to Chinese restaurants in the '60s.  Any family trip to a restaurant was a rare treat, and Chinese restaurants were the best!  
But there were always restrictions, usually monetary about what we could order, and the PUPU platter was always off-limits!
We would look on with envy at the other tables who ordered this magnificent appetizer: an enticing assortment of tasty tidbits, most often with a seductive Sterno flame in the center to re-heat the items, and a sea of sauces for dipping.  It always looked so good, but it was declared to be too expensive by the parental units.

When I finally had the resources to order a PUPU platter for myself (and my guest), it was, of course, anti-climactic.  All flash and show, mediocre substance: "shrimp toast" with little evidence of shrimp, semi-soggy slices of eggroll,...

Such are the lessons of so-called "adulthood".
Great puzzle. Great fill.
fantastic Saturday puzzle!!!!! I hope everyone is having a good weekend!

I often look at XW Stats after I finish. I will never come close to the median time but I generally have the same experience as the average solver there. If they find the puzzle ‚Äúeasy,‚Äù solving within about, say, three minutes under their average time, that‚Äôs about where I am with my own time.

Today, however, it was pretty crushing to see the average solver finished 28% under their average time, as I found this quite difficult, finishing a minute and a half over my average time. I had never heard of PUPU, or ANTINOVEL, and had difficulty getting on the constructor‚Äôs wavelength. 

This is not a complaint‚Ä¶the crossword is the crossword is the crossword. It‚Äôs just that sometimes it‚Äôs in my wheelhouse and other days I‚Äôm lost asea, to use a common crossword fill.

Still, I finished and with only one lookup, it‚Äôs 70 degrees, I‚Äôm on my deck drinking coffee, looking at the woods behind the house, and listening to an album my daughter gave me because she thought I‚Äôd like it, which I do.

'Twas a ROLLICKING good puzzle, YES INDEEDY.

Toy chests before PROP ROOMS, but that was quickly "crossed" out.


IN ANY CASE, I'm still waiting for the GOON TRIAL.

Someone help me out here...I got PUPU platter easily, but it immediately evoked a memory of a character saying, "PUPU-PUU platter." Does anyone know what TV show or movie was just tickled in my brain?

Mr. Dolan and NYT thank you for a delightful Saturday morning solve!!! I love a themeless puzzle and new discoveries within said puzzle. Off to read about the case of the Ratman! (And possibly get nap-trapped by my cats!) Have a great weekend all ü´∂üèª

Another Kyle, eh?
I certainly fell for some misdirects:  AXIOMS before PROOFS, and I BET for "No duh!".... and (like Linda Jo) TOY CHEST for the Other Kind of Play... and I had I CAN'T for 2D before I was persuaded to rethink that corner.

40D reminded me of the enormous TAIL FINS of the "Belch-Fire Eight" in Sunday funny paper cartoon fame... not to mention the infamous Edsels even though it was the FISH-face front end that really won the "1950s car design" booby prize.  

On with the lovely day....

Ooohh! And one more puzzle find. A Sunday from September 29, 1991 by Nancy Nicholson Joline with the title "Vowel play." Theme answers in that one - all straightforwardly clued: LILIUOKALANI POLLAIUOLO LEEUWENHOEK OEILDEBOEUF SEANOFAOLAIN ONOMATOPOEIA MOOGOOGAIPAN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=9/29/1991&g=16&d=D .....

That south east corner has an astonishing number of options for the incautious puzzler - I felt very lucky to escape before drinking three coffees then twitching all day! 

(39D: Fasting? FISHdaY? Aha, FISHFRY!! And let's not even get into Plump little baby fingers, 48D)

Nice puzzle!
Brand associated with push-ups? ü§£ü§£ü§£ü§£
Solved this while being nap trapped by my 8 week old!

That was as hard as yesterday‚Äôs was simple. It was the ‚ÄòAmericanisms‚Äô that got me, as they will occasionally. LLC=Ltd in the UK. As I only had C for ages I was stuck. PUPU? I‚Äôve only discovered by reading the comments that it‚Äôs a Chinese type food dish. Not knowing 1A held up almost everything in that quarter, as I had no clue for 3, 6, or 9D. Though of course I‚Äôve spent years of my life (it seems) being 1A‚Äôd without knowing what to call it. Ah me.

Still, a fun, crunchy outing. SHONDALAND WONDERBRA and ANTINOVEL were helpful gimmes and the rest fell gradually. 

Memories of being faced with a gigantic Eva and her ‚Äògirls‚Äô on the Chiswick flyover on my daily commute. It did nothing for us women I have to say, neither the over exposed vision of a beautiful half naked woman, nor the actual bras, which were bulky monstrosities.

Oh. and what the heck - one more puzzle find. A Sunday from October 31, 1999 by Frank A. Longo with the title "Twin states." Some theme clues and answers with the rebuses in parentheses. LIFETI(ME)(ME)MBERSHIPS COMIN(GA)(GA)INST EL(IL)(IL)LYANDCOMPANY CNNHEADLI(NE)(NE)WS ROY(AL)(AL)BERTHALL SCENESFRO(MA)(MA)LL SING(IN)(IN)THERAIN BE(AR)(AR)ESEMBLANCETO CLAU(DE)(DE)BUSSY A(MI)(MI)SSINGSOMETHING Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/31/1999&g=58&d=D ...
A very satisfying solve.   Many thanks.
Re the sleeping cat - we call that cat trapped, maybe a clue for another puzzle!

A satisfying one that started with the feeling that I would only ever manage the NW corner, but like a good crossword should, it led me just clearly enough into the next chunk and the next. Really fun, faster than my average time. 

Also, I like the crossing at 24. I knew SHEL well as a kid, with an English teacher grandma who made sure I had all his poetry books, but I was oddly delighted a couple decades later to learn that another big outlet for his work was... Playboy Magazine. Something about a writer who knew so well how to do insightful kid stuff for kids and decidedly adult stuff for adults is appealing. 

Happy Saturday to you all.
I am almost always NAPTRAPPED while solving the daily crossword! And hoping for no poo-poo platters!

Sheesh, it took me 15 minutes to nearly complete the puzzle (fairly easy for a Saturday) and another 10 to work out my problem in the northeast corner. For 34A, I have only ever seen and used OBVS, not OBVI. The devious clue misdirect at 18A (not had by) further muddied the waters and had me stuck on 14D (face justice) forever. When I finally realized 14D was not one indecipherable word, nor two, but three (!), I got the happy music. WHEW!

YOW is one of Zippy‚Äôs catchphrases. Loved so many of this puzzles words including that one. Definitely having fun, no yet. https://zippythepinhead.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=PROD&Product_Code=yow2&Category_Code=cfps&Product_Count=2

Really enjoyed this one. As a parent, some answers came easily. The ones I didn't know right off the bat I was able to figure out using some logic with the clues, so that made the solving experience a lot of fun for me!
Completely BSed my way through NW. Never heard of that cosmetics brand. Smells a little like a marketing ploy üòú
Fun but pretty easy.  I must say that the Saturday Los Angeles Times puzzle is always much more difficult.

Thank goodness Oregon isn‚Äôt the same length as ANAHEIM: NW quadrant could have been a real mess if my (questionable) memory of some hockey ducks had fit. 

GOTOcourt unfortunately fit, but crosses soon straightened me out. 

Not the bear I was expecting after yesterday: 12 minutes faster than average. These days, I‚Äôm in no mood to complain about fun. Nice puzzle.

Me I thought it was "lift and separate." But, what do I know. Pleasent solve for a Saturday.

thank you Kyle
Where do I find the XW stats that someone mentioned in today‚Äôs comments?
I wanted 59A to be Frolicking so bad. Rollicking is new one for me.

I don't have much to say on this one - it was fine - but I came in to recommend the Saturday LA Times puzzle by Rebecca Goldstein & Rafael Musa.

It's one of the most challenging I've played in a long time.  I wasn't sure I'd finish.  Fair in the end!
Today I learned that ‚Äòrollicking‚Äô is yet another word that separates the English speaking world. It has an entirely different meaning to a Brit!

If the novel was "something new," wouldn't an ANTINOVEL be a return to the classical form? Nope, it means the opposite, as in, dispensing with all conventions. I don't believe I've ever read one of those.
Did NOT enjoy it at all.

I liked this puzzle. 

Mostly because it was my 2000th solve in a row! 

That number has seemed so far away for a long time. But doing the crosswords every day has been a great source of entertainment, accomplishment, satisfaction, education, challenge, ‚Ä¶ I could go on. 

One of the best things has been getting to the point where my mindset is that I can always finish the puzzle. It might take me a while, and the hard ones won‚Äôt be done in one sitting, but I‚Äôll figure it out. I think that carries over subconsciously to other areas of life, and that ain‚Äôt bad.

Zing! Blue, blue is the night, stormy un-dark. Sixty years before, üî≤ü©ºüóø, Oreo, https://youtu.be/vKXuM-Ez_Q0?si=b2u9Djvy57K6NTmQ fell silent, all was cacophony. Professor Erno ate a danish, which he hated, for his lover was dirty. Joyce, his lover, did not exist in this realm. Zing. Green.

Really enjoyed this one. Solved it a little more quickly than my average, but had delightful chewiness created by my own incorrect fills the first time through: 'leadingman' in the NW, 'soya' and 'ante' in the SW. 

And 'axiOmS' for the mathematician's output. (Although, aren't they more likely to be used as input? I guess they were all output at some point. Back when they were mere postulates. But I digress.)

Last to fall was the sleeping baby clue. Because the initial letter for the vacation spot could have been anything, I had to use (ahem) logic to figure out a cute, suitable, three letter rhyming word to start that phrase.

KIDTRAPPED then DADTRAPPED, I thought DARTY was close enough to DODGY but NASTY made more sense ‚Ä¶ finally NAPTRAPPED fell into place, a little better than my average time.

Loved the PHLOX / AZALEA / ALOE waterfall, and struggled a bit with PUPU / POKE / PUDGY.

Cheers!
The entire NW corner is ridiculous. You can tell the constructor had to google all kinds of obscure stuff just to finish this one off. Meh.

Y'all, I twisted my brain silly but could not make my MAIDENFORM BRA fit in or around the spaces. üòÇ 
Fun puzzle! Thank you.

Turns out JUST PEACHY contains the same number of letters as YES INDEEDY üòÇ

I struggle so much with slang terms and this puzzle had way too much of that. Never heard of NAPTRAPPED but worse than that is OBVI. Never heard anyone say that.

This was a fun one, just about the right level for a Saturday challenge where the tricky clues took some thinking, but I wasn't beating my head against the wall. Nicely done. Although I will admit to being a little disappointed that NO__ for "Something you should avoid" didn't turn out to be the NOID.

I mean, not really, since I can't exactly lay across myself, but I sure can burrow into a nice napping position with the blankies juuuussssst right‚Äîand feel wonderfully trapped by the wonderfulness!  I know this makes no sense, but I'm okay with that and ohhhh, I do love a good nap! Mmmm!

Still, that was my last area to complete... it took a long time to come up with NASTY. I was a bit blocked by thinking of AWFUL, but I was pretty sure of ACTIONHERO, fortunately.  

But no idea of PTOWN, caNS before TINS, ANAHEIM was somewhere in my bingo ball cage brain and eventually popped up with a couple of crosses. Kept thinking of emotional breakdowns at 19A. Don't know why... I mean, it's not like I had a small one the other day or anything.... Nope, not me!!  Har!!  DODIRTY did not come easily and isn't familiar‚Äîthough now I'm singing dirty deeds‚Äîdone dirt cheap‚Äîin my head. 

So, that was my toughest area but it all eventually pieced together without much trouble. Once I finally had NASTY (Ms. Jackson if you're NASTY) in place after getting all but 3D, the only thing that made sense there was a P, even if I didn't know what PTOWN meant at the moment. Huzzah!!

INANYCASE, nice puzzle! Definitely on the faster side again, even with those slowdowns, with some crunch to it. I like the cut of its JIB!

Will definitely re-post this tomorrow. Another one of a kind. One of the most amazing pieces of construction I've encountered. A Sunday from January 18, 2015 by Joe Krozel with the title "Changelings." Six 20 letter theme answers in that one, each of them consisting of five 4 letter words. And the progression of those words was to change just one letter from one to the next. Those answers: HUGELUGELUGSLOGSLOTS MAIDSAIDSANDSANKSINK PALEPALSPASSLASSLESS KIDSKISSMISSMOSSMOST LOUDLOUTLOSTLASTCAST WILTWILLFILLFULLFUEL Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/18/2015&g=100&d=A .....

@Andrzej Lee (short for leeward) in this context is the opposite of windward.  Windward would be the side of the mountain or island or ship exposed to the prevailing wind, whereas lee or leeward would be the other side, less exposed, more protected from the wind.

As clued, REPENT might refer to regretting and changing one's behavior. i.e. repent of one's misdeeds.

@Mean Old Lady

Well, I've never wanted children and don't have any. Thus I've never been and likely never will be responsible for the development of any baby. I'm not sure I'd be able to deal with it. There is a small but not insignificant percentage of people who regret having children, and I've always had reason to believe I would find myself in this group. I'm lazy and can't handle responsibility, especially for others. I'm happiest engaging in shallow pursuits, and I don't care about leaving behind any legacy. Also, I've literally never seen parents with children and though: oh, yeah, I'd like to be them! (Or even join them). Vacation with children? Climbing? Going to a museum? Enjoying a meal at a restaurant? Playing video games? Reading in peace? Working at home? The very idea of having to include a baby or child in any of the stuff I enjoy or need to do is scary to me. I don't see it.

Also, some of the most unpleasant of my memories of the past 10 years (other than true family tragedies and periods of illness) involved being forced to interact with kids in the family. It's all so alien to me, paradoxically tiring and boring at the same time. 

Strangely, both my mother and father always obviously loved being parents, yet I didn't inherit their parental instincts.

@Nancy J. 
Your comment about ERNO strikes me as a great example of something I‚Äôve noticed about NYT crosswords: the strong tendency to play fair by giving us an inference pathway even when presenting us what may appear to be wildly obscure trivia. Laszlo is the most distinctively Hungarian name I can think of, so it makes sense to try the only distinctively Hungarian four-letter first name most of us know. If the cosmetics czar had been named Dave Laszlo or Sven Laszlo I don‚Äôt think the editors would have done us dirty. In other words, I like the way one can so often use general knowledge where it might look like unreasonably specific knowledge is called for, and that seems deliberate.

@Paul Turner

I couldn't agree more.  If so-called "Naticks" aren't resolvable by crosses, they are by logic.  The editors deserve a big hand for the excellent work they do every day to entertain us.
